column5:
तल उल्लखित प्रतिवेदन nepalmonitor.org ले online मार्फत प्राप्त गरेको हो।
NepalMonitor.org has received the following report via online form:
<p><span>  </span></p>
आदर्णिय,
म सचिन कुमार सिंग, गाँउ : मधेपुरा-१, जिल्ला: सप्तर, अंचल: सगरमाथा, थाना: हनुमान नगर, पोस्ट: बभनगमा कट्टी।
हाल मा भारतको बामबेमा एउटा IT कमपनीमा प्रोजेक्ट लिडर (chief Engineer) को रुपमा काम गर्दै छु। यहाँ बस्ने सुविधा नभएकाले मैले आफ्नो परिवारलाई बाध्यताले गर्दा केहि समयका लागि गाउँमै (नेपालमा) छोड्नु परेकोछ। मैले ३ वर्ष अगाडी पटना, बिहार, भारत कि केटी संग बिहे गरेको थिए र हाल हामी संग एउटा २ बर्षको छोरा पनि छ र उ अहिले आमा संगै गाँउमा बसिरहेकोछ। बिहे पछि नेपालको कानुन अनुसार उले नागरिकता पनि प्राप्त गरेको छ। जसले गर्दा उ पनि अहिले नेपाली नागरिक भएको छ।
<p><span>  </span></p>
मेरो बुवा मदन कुमार सिंग, आमा दिनेश सिंग र भाई रोसन कुमार सिंग तिनै जना एकदमै लालची मान्छे हुन् र उनीहरु दाइजोको कुर लिएर मेरो श्रीमती र छोरालाई विभिन्ना खालको यातना दिरहेका छन् । हाल म भारतमा छु र मेरो छोरा गाँउमा एकदमै बिरामी भएको छ। मलाई थाहा छैन तर संका छ कि उनीहरुले मेरो परिवारलाई कुनै नोकसान पुर्याउन्छन् किनकी उनीहरु सधैं म र मेरो परिवारलाई धम्की दिरहन्छन्।
<p><span>  </span></p>
त्यसैले म यस जानकारी मार्फत उनीहरुको सुरक्षाको लागि FRI दर्ता गराउँदै छु र मेरो परिवारलाई कुनै खालको नोक्सानी व त्यसतो घट्ना भएमा माथी उल्लेख व्यक्तीहरु जिम्मेवार हुनेछन्। म १२ नोवेम्बरमा २०१२ मा नेपाल आउँदै छु र कुनै जानकारीको लागि सम्पर्क गर्नु होला।
<p><span>  </span></p>
तपाईको
सचिन कुमार सिंग

<p><span>  </span></p>
I Sachin Kumar Singh,Village : Ko. Madhepura-1,District : Saptari,Zone : Sagarmatha, Thana : Hanumannagar,
Post : Babhangama Katti, currently working in Bombay,India as a Project Lead (Chief Engineer) in one of
IT company.Due to accommodation related issues I was not able to bring my family here and was compelled to
leave my family in my village(Nepal) for some time.I have married to a girl in Patna,Bihar India some three years back
and blessed with a Son who is 2 years old as of now.After marriage they have also acquired citizenship of
Nepal as per the law and now they are also the responsible citizen of Nepal.

My father Madan Kumar Singh, mother Dinesh Singh and brother Roshan Kumar Singh, all three are very greedy person
and they keeps on torching my wife and son for dowry related issues.Right now I'm in Bombay,India and my Son is
also very sick at my village. So not sure but I suspect if they do any harm to my family because they keeps on
threatening my family including me everyday.
<p><span>  </span></p>
Thus, I'm here by filing an FIR for their security and the above
mentioned persons will be responsible for any damage
or for any such incident.Moreover, I will be available in Nepal by 12th
Nov 2012 i.e. after a week and will be available
for any further inquiry any time if required.
<p><span>  </span></p>

column2: Village banishes woman, man for 'illicit ties'
column5:
MITHILESH YADAV

SIRAHA, Oct 7: A married woman and a man have been banished from a village in Siraha district for allegedly having illicit relations.

A panchayat (meeting) of local people decided to banish a 28-year-old woman and a 22-year-old man, both belonging to the Yadav caste, from Ayodhyapur (Nepal Monitor edit: "Ayodhyanagar" is in Siraha) VDC of Siraha district two days ago. The matter was brought to light at a press conference on Saturday by a local network of human rights organizations.

According to Dev Kumari Mahara, a Siraha-based human rights activist, the villagers had shorn off their hair, smeared soot on their faces and garlanded them with shoes and sandals before hounding them out of the village.

“What is even more shocking is the police were present when the villagers committed such a horrible deed,” said Sunil Kumar Sah, another human rights activist in Siraha. “By not doing anything, the police lent moral support to this barbaric act.”

A police team led by an assistant sub-inspector from Gol-bazaar of Siraha was present at the panchayat. When the panchayat decided to banish the two from the village, the police simply walked away, reads a joint statement released by various Siraha-based human rights organizations.

According to Mahara, when the victimized woman sought help from the police, she was advised to go elsewhere and start a new life as no one could go against the panchayat´s decision. The panchayat, a traditional assembly of ´gentlemen´ and elders for addressing local issues, still functions in most villages in the Tarai, although they have no legal status.

DSP Krishna Hari Sharma admitted to having prior information about the issue but said he did not anticipate that the panchayat would go to that extent. According to him, Rajendra Yadav, one of the villagers directly involved in the incident, has been arrested while others have fled the village.

The victimized woman has refuted villagers´ allegation that she was having an extra-marital affair with the man who happens to be her brother-in-law. Her husband is not ready to believe that she cheated on him. “I don´t doubt my wife´s character. I am still ready to accept her,” he said. “But, I can´t go against the villagers´ decision either.”

The expelled woman and man are now sheltering in Bishnupurkatti VDC. “My name has been tarnished; and now I find it difficult to live on,” said the woman. “The villagers punished me without any evidence.”

column2: 96 GBV cases recorded in a month
column5:
KATHMANDU: A total of 96 cases of gender-based violence was recorded in Nepal in the past 30 days, a non-governmental organisation working for women’s rights said today.

Women in Nepal are still suffering from physical and mental torture, said Women’s Rehabilitation Centre (WOREC). A press statement issued by the organisation said some women were killed by their in-laws for failing to bring sufficient dowry with them.

The centre said it has recorded 96 Gender-based Violence (GBV) cases nationwide during the month of Bhadra (mid August-mid September).

Among the cases, 42 were related to domestic violence, 26 to physical assaults, 10 to mental torture and two to polygamy, said the report adding that 10 murder cases and four attempt to murder cases were also recorded in the past 30 days.

WOREC said 11 women became victims of social violence –– four were accused of practicing witchcraft and six were beaten up.

The report also showed that 13 women were raped, two were subjected to attempt to rape and five to sexual violence.

The organisation had recorded 114 cases of gender-based violence against women last month.

column2: 18 year old boy commits suicide after elicit relations exposed.
column5:
<p>मकवानपुर जिला काकडा गा बि स वडनँ १ बसने बषॅ १८ को  बिमराज चेपाङ २०६९आषबिन ९ गते आतमा हतते गरी मरेको काराण ८ गते बीहान छिमेकी ईमान चेपाङ को सिरीमती रिता चेपाङ सँगा योन समपकॅ गरी रहेको नगना अबसथामा आफनै सिरमान ईमान सिङ ले फेलापारेको र बिमराज भागेको १४ घणटा पछी आफनै घर समपकॅम आएको ९ गते छलफल गने हला भयपछ बिहान रुखम झुनडीयर मरेको अबसथामा भेटियो र ईमानसिङ र रिता कोभने पुन सिरमान सिरमतिको समबनध सुरुभयो |</p>
<p>18 year old, Mr. Bimaraj Chepang committed suicide by hanging himself from a tree on 25th September, 2012. The reason was that Mr. Bimaraj was having a relationship with his neighbour, Mrs. Rita chepang, and both were caught having sex by the husband of Rita, Mr. Iman Chepang on 24th September, 2012. Mr. Bimaraj escaped from the site and came in contact with his relatives after 14 hrs. Then he came to know that a community meeting was planned for the morning after. The next day he was found dead after he hung himself from the tree. </p>

column2: Gang rape in Kathmandu.
column5:
A mentally ill, elderly woman was unfortunately gang-raped in Kathmandu on August the 24th. The rape resulted in mutilation so severe that the woman requires surgery because her uterus is essentially removed from her body. In a situation like this the Nepali government is supposed to provide free treatment, but due to government negligence they are refusing this woman treatment. She is currently
under the care of Raksha Nepal (www.rakshanepal.org)

column2: Court Slaps 12 Years Jail Term to Rapist
column5:
Kailali/January 4

The district court Kailali has sentenced Prakash Bhatta, 30, of Darakh VDC-7 to 12 years and six months in prison for raping a 7-year-old girl of same place. A single bench of Justice Bishnu Subedi gave the verdict on January 3. The court has also asked him to provide 75 thousand rupees to the victim as relief.

Bhatta has been sent to the district prison following the court order.



Mother of the victim had filed a case against Bhatta at the area police office Sukkhad on January 4, 2012 accusing him of raping the girl on the same day. Bhatta had raped the girl after taking her to Shaileshwori Community forest from a neighbor's house where she was sleeping. He was arrested on the same day.



Medical check-up of the girl was held at the Seti Zonal Hospital.
Sur Bahadur Pariyar

column2: INSEC: Husband Kills First Wife
column5:
Terhathum/November 11
Dhan Maya Tamang, 48, of Ishibu VDC-6 has been killed by her husband Prem Bahadur Tamang, 50 on November 8.

Prem Bahadur, who had second marriage with Indra Kumari Limbu, 30 of Ishibu VDC-7 on July 28 this year, had been frequently beating his first wife Dhan Maya and threatening to kill her, said neighbor, Brikha Bahadur Tamang.

Prem Bahadur had summoned Dhan Maya into his room while she had been washing utensils after supper in the evening on November 8. Prem and his second wife Indra Kumari beat her to death, locals said, adding the couple is at large following the incident.

Locals said that they came to know about the incident on November 9 and police took the dead body to District Hospital the next day. Relatives of the deceased collected the body and cremated it today.

Hunt for the couple involved in the murder is underway, said Laxman Giri, DSP at Terhathum District Police Office.
Chhatra Rimal
column6: Gender Based Violence - WHRD, INSEC,

column2: Urge to Help in Searching for Missing Daughter
column5:
Banke /November 11
Radha Harijan, of Nepalgunj Municipality-2 has urged INSEC to help in searching for her six-year-old daughter Meera Harijan who has been missing for six days on November 11.

The mother said that her missing daughter Meera, one grader at Mahendra Higher Secondary School in Nepalgunj, has not been in the contact of family and relatives since November 5.

The victim family had filed an application at District Police Office seeking to search for the missing daughter on November 7.

The poor Harijan family has also filed applications in various offices including NHRC, CWIN, Maiti Nepal, District Child Welfare Committee among others urging to help in searing for missing Meena.

The mother said that her daughter might be taken to India to sell her. "I have made contact to all my relatives but her whereabouts are still unknown," says Radha.
Search for the missing minor girl is underway, Uday Tamang, DSP at Banke District Police Office said.
Narayan Subedi
column6: Human Trafficking, INSEC,
